questions.text: The girl seen in the image has had history of severe sunburns after just a few minutes in the sun, she also has history of photosensitivity & severe freckling in the sun exposed areas. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Xeroderma Pigmentosa.

 

Option B.

 

  • The image shows a girl with Xeroderma Pigmentosa. It is characterised by defective Nucleotide Excision Repair.
  • A rare autosomal recessive genetic condition called Xeroderma pigmentosa causes clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to UV radiation and other carcinogens as a result of faulty DNA repair.

 

Important clinical features are:

 

  • First Stage: Child is asymptomatic at birth. Diffuse erythema scaling & freckle like lesions over the sun exposed regions of the body at around 6 months of age.
  • Second Stage: Poikiloderma is a characteristic feature of the second stage of Xeroderma Pigmentosa.
  • Poikiloderma is a special skin lesion with a triad of features {ATP}
    • Atrophy of skin
    • Telangiectasia (Permanently dilated blood vessels)
    • Pigment abnormalities (Dyspigmentation, both hypo & hyper)
  • Poikiloderma may be congenital or acquired. It is associated with mycosis fungoides, dermatomyositis etc.

 

Third stage:

 

  • Increased incidence of Cutaneous malignancies like:
    • Squamous Cell Carcinoma
    • Malignant melanoma
    • Basal Cell Carcinoma
    • Fibrosarcoma.
  • The final diagnosis of Xeroderma Pigmentosa can be confirmed by special laboratory tests by the examining the DNA damage repair in cells from cultures exposed to UV radiation. The most common tests are skin biopsy & culture of skin fibroblasts.
  • There is no cure for Xeroderma Pigmentosa.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Minimise exposure to sunlight
  • Regular dermatological care,
  • Surgery for recurrent tumours excision.
  • Follow up every 3 months.
  • Genetic counselling is important in a family that has an affected child & is considering having more children.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Blooms Syndrome:

 

  • It is characterized by short stature, sun-sensitive skin lesions, and an increased risk of cancers, but the freckling noted in the clinical picture is more characteristic of XP.

 

Option C. Warts:

 

  • They are benign growths caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) and do not have a relationship with sun exposure or photosensitivity.

 

Option D. SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus):

 

  • SLE can cause photosensitivity and skin rashes, but the distribution and chronicity of freckling seen here are more specific to XP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The history of severe sunburns, photosensitivity, and severe freckling in sun-exposed areas are classic signs of Xeroderma Pigmentosum.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume II Chapter 78 Page No 78.1

 

Harpers Illustrated Biochemistry 30th Edition Page Number 390

 

Harpers Illustrated Biochemistry 31st Edition Page Number 370

choices.text: An Adverse Reaction to Drugs

questions.text: Cutis Marmorata occurs due to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exposure to Cold Temperature

 

Option C.

 

  • Cutis marmorata, also known as physiological livedo reticularis, describes the pinkish-blue mottled or marbled appearance of the skin that occurs when exposed to cold temperatures.


 

Fig: Cutis marmorata

 

  • During infancy, about half of all children exhibit a noticeable marbling pattern on their skin when exposed to cooler temperatures.
  • This effect arises from the simultaneous dilation and contraction of the superficial capillaries and may continue throughout early childhood.
  • However, the skin returns to its regular appearance when warmed again, indicating that this is a natural physiological response and does not necessitate any intervention.
  • Nevertheless, persistent cutis marmorata may be observed in individuals with trisomies 18 and 21.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Exposure to hot temperature

 

 

Erythema Ab Igne over thigh

 

 

Option B. An adverse reaction to drugs

 

  • They can cause various skin manifestations, including rashes, urticaria, or specific reactions like Stevens-Johnson syndrome, but not cutis marmorata.

 

Option D. Humidity

 

  • It is not known to cause cutis marmorata. High humidity can lead to other skin issues like sweating and chafing, but it does not cause the vascular changes seen in cutis marmorata.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cutis marmorata is a skin condition characterized by a marbled appearance of the skin, resulting from exposure to cold temperatures due to the vascular response of constriction and dilation.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 125, Page No 125.7

choices.text: Contact Dermatitis due to Henna

questions.text: A School-Going Child who had Applied Henna comes to Dermatology OPD with the following lesions. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dermatitis Artefacta

 

Option B:

 

The given image points towards a likely diagnosis of Dermatitis Artefacta.

 

  • Dermatitis Artefacta is an artefactual skin disease produced entirely by the actions of the fully aware patient. There is no rational motive for this behavior
  • Clues to diagnosis - symmetrical placement of lesions in accessible locations on the face and neck. Additionally, the lesions appear to be healing in a variety of stages, much like an abrasion would. This is a psychological ailment.
  • Thus the visible symptoms of Dermatitis Artefacta serve as a non-verbal communication - a ′cry for attention and help′ from a patient incapable of meaningful verbal communication.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Contact dermatitis –

 

  • Chemicals in Henna may cause this condition. Papulovesiculation is present. Normally, henna is not applied to the face as in this instance.

 

Option C: Polymorphic light eruption (PLE):

 

  • Lesions will appear on the hands, face, and neck as part of a polymorphic light eruption, but they will be small, itchy papules or Papulovesicles on an erythematous background. They will also be monomorphic (unlike as the name suggests).

 

Option D: Vitiligo

 

  • It presents as Depigmented / hypopigmented areas, but not as hyperpigmentation as shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dermatitis Artefacta is a condition where self-inflicted skin lesions are produced intentionally by the patient, often for psychological reasons.
  • It is important to recognize and understand this condition for appropriate management.

 

Ref: Online resource: https://ijdvl.com/dermatitis-artefacta-a-focal-suicide/

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of this condition affecting Hair?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichothiodystrophy

 

Option C:

 

  • The given clinical image of hair seen under polarizing microscopy reveals tiger tail banding (alternating light and dark bands) characteristic of trichothiodystrophy.
  • Trichothiodystrophy/PIBIDS Syndrome: Autosomal Recessive Condition
  • Photosensitivity (unlike XP, has NO increased skin cancer risk)
  • Ichthyosis
  • Brittle hair (short/sparse on scalp/brows/lashes w/alternating light and dark bands on polarizing light microscopy (“tiger-tail” abnormality)
  • Intellectual impairment and ataxia
  • Decreased fertility/hypogonadism
  • Short stature

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Trichorrhexis Nodosa

 

  • It is associated with node formation.
  • It may be seen in arginosuccinic aciduria.
  • Characterized by classical appearance as if two paint brushes are rubbing against each other described as Thrust Paintbrush appearance.

 

 

Option B: Trichorrhexis invaginata:

 

  • Also known as Bamboo hair having Golf tee or Ball & Socket appearance, in which the distal part of the hair shaft is compressed against the dilated and cupped proximal shaft.
  • Seen in Netherton’s syndrome.

 

 

Option D: Monilethrix: Beaded hair seen in Menkes disease.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • "Tigertail" banding of hair under polarized light microscopy is indicative of trichothiodystrophy, a condition characterized by brittle hair with reduced sulfur content and potentially associated with multi-system involvement.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 9th Edition Page No. 1537

 

Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Pages No. 65.33, 68.21, 78.10 89.53-54

choices.text: Ball & Socket Hair Deformity seen
Abnormal Keratinisation in Distal Hair Shaft

questions.text: FALSE about Trichorrhexis Invaginata among the following options?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abnormal Keratinisation in Distal Hair Shaft

 

Option D:

 

  • In Trichorrhexis invaginata Abnormal keratinisation in proximal hair shaft is seen (NOT distal)

 

Explanation:

 

Trichorrhexis Invaginata (“Bamboo Hair”)

 

  • It is associated with Netherton syndrome (Option B), an autosomal recessive disorder caused by SPINK5 gene mutations. Netherton syndrome presents with a triad of ichthyosis linearis circumflexa, atopy, and hair abnormalities, including Trichorrhexis invaginata (TI) and trichorrhexis nodosa (TN).
  • Trichorrhexis invaginata is indeed associated with bamboo hair (option A), which is a characteristic feature where the hair appears weak and constricted at regular intervals, resembling a bamboo stalk.
  • Ball and socket hair deformity (Option C) is another feature seen in TI, where the distal end of the hair shaft appears as if it has a ball-and-socket joint.

 

 

  • Hair abnormality arises in infancy, presents with short, sparse, and very fragile hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trichorrhexis Invaginata (TI), often referred to as "Bamboo Hair," is associated with Abnormal Keratinization in the proximal Hair Shaft and is a characteristic feature of Netherton Syndrome.
  • Understanding this condition is important for recognizing Hair Abnormalities in patients with Netherton Syndrome.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 89, Page No 89.53

questions.text: A child with fever had multiple skin lesions on face and upper extremities as shown in the below image, on microscopic examination the skin lesions are seen to have neutrophilic and histiocytic infiltration in the dermis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sweet Syndrome

 

Option A:

 

Sweet syndrome (Acute Febrile Neutrophilic Dermatosis)

 

Skin Manifestations:

 

  • Tender Red Papules, Nodules and eventually plaques distributed over the head, neck, upper trunk and upper arms.

 

Diagnostic criteria for Sweet Syndrome

 

Major:

 

  • Acute onset of typical lesions as described above
  • Histopathological findings: Neutrophilic and histiocytic infiltration in the dermis.

 

Minor:

 

  • Fever >38°C
  • Association with malignancy, inflammatory disorder or pregnancy, or antecedent URTI or GI infection
  • Excellent response to systemic corticosteroids.
  • Abnormal laboratory values at presentation (3/4 required: ESR >20 mm; leukocytes >8000; neutrophils>70%; elevated C-reactive protein)

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Behcet's syndrome

 

  • It is characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions, but it does not typically present with neutrophilic and histiocytic infiltration in the dermis.

 

Option C. Pyoderma gangrenosum

 

  • It is characterized by rapidly progressing skin ulcers with a purple border and is often associated with underlying systemic diseases, which is different from the described case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sweet syndrome, also known as acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis, presents with fever and painful skin lesions showing neutrophilic and histiocytic infiltration in the dermis.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition, Chapter 148 Page No 148.6

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can cause Aplasia Cutis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carbimazole

 

Explanation:

 

Aplasia Cutis: Congenital absence of skin, with or without the absence of underlying structures such as bone. It most commonly affects the scalp, just lateral to the midline (70%).

 

  • Lesions are usually non-inflammatory, well-demarcated and have a variable appearance depending on the size (0.5–10 cm), extent, depth and degree of healing and scarring.
  • The various causative pathophysiological mechanisms include genetic factors, intrauterine trauma, fetus papyraceus, intrauterine infections by varicellaor herpes viruses, drugs including Methimazole, Carbimazole and Misoprostol, feto-fetal transfusion, early rupture of amniotic membrane forming amniotic bands and abnormal elastic fiber biomechanical forces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aplasia cutis: Congenital absence of skin, with or without the absence of underlying structures such as bone.
  • Methimazole, Carbimazole and Misoprostol are important drugs causing Aplasia Cutis.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 75 Page No 75.19

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Chapter: 64 Page Number 1226

questions.text: Which of the following disease has a Blaschkoid Pattern of Cutaneous Lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Incontinentiapigmenti

 

Explanation:

 

  • Incontinentia pigmenti has a Blaschkoid pattern of cutaneous lesions
  • Herpes zoster has a Dermatomal /Zosteriform distribution.
  • In Herpes labialis & genitalis, which are produced by Herpes simplex viruses, grouped vesicles can be seen near lips & genitalia respectively.

 

  • Incontinentia pigmenti (IP) is a rare Xlinked dominant multisystemic ectodermal dysplasia that is usually lethal in males and that presents classically in females with skin lesions, teeth abnormalities, alopecia, nail dystrophy, and ocular and neurological findings.
  • Skin changes have 4 stages as described below:

1. Bullous stage I Erythematous vesicular rash following Blaschko’s lines.

 

 

2.  Verrucous stage II, occurring mainly on the limbs

 

 

3. Stage III hyperpigmented streaks and whorls along Blaschko’s lines begin within months and fade in adolescence.

 

 

4. Stage IV patients have pale, hairless, atrophic linear streaks or patches Hypopigmentary changes mostly on the lower extremities.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Incontinentia pigmenti is characterized by a Blaschkoid pattern of cutaneous lesions, which is a distinctive feature of this rare genetic disorder.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 70 Page No 70.11

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Chapter: 62 Page Number 1170

choices.text: Electron Microscopy of Platelets
Check for WASP Gene Mutation

questions.text: A boy with Small Sized Platelets and a Platelet Count of 20,000 presents with Petechiae, Melena & Atopic Dermatitis. What is the next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Check for WASP Gene Mutation

 

Option D:

 

  • This is the most appropriate next step. WAS is caused by mutations in the WASP gene, and this patient's presentation is highly suggestive of this diagnosis.
  • Confirming the diagnosis with genetic testing for the WASP gene mutation would be the most direct and specific approach.
  • The clinical presentation of a boy with Petechiae, Melena, Atopic Dermatitis, and a low Platelet Count (Thrombocytopenia) raises the suspicion for Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (WAS), which is a rare X-Linked Recessive Disease.
  • This condition is characterized by Eczema (Atopic Dermatitis), Thrombocytopenia (Low Platelet Count), Immune Deficiency, and a predisposition to developing Autoimmune conditions and Malignancies.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antiplatelet Antibodies:

 

  • These are typically assessed when immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) is suspected. In ITP, the immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys platelets.
  • However, the presence of eczema along with thrombocytopenia and gastrointestinal bleeding (melena) is more suggestive of WAS than ITP.

 

Option B. Bone Marrow Examination:

 

  • This test is important when there is suspicion of bone marrow failure or infiltration by malignant cells, which might be causing the low platelet count.
  • Given the patient's symptoms, bone marrow failure is less likely, and other signs of marrow failure (such as anemia and leukopenia) are typically also present.

 

Option C. Electron Microscopy of Platelets:

 

  • This is a more specialized diagnostic test and is not routinely used in the initial evaluation of thrombocytopenia.
  • It might be considered in certain rare platelet disorders where the platelet structure might be altered, but it is not the first-line investigation in this clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a male patient with thrombocytopenia, small-sized platelets, eczema, and bleeding manifestations, the most likely diagnosis is Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and the most definitive next step in diagnosis is to check for mutations in the WASP gene.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page No 147.13

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 981

questions.text: A farmer presented to the outpatient department with a non-tender, non-mobile, non-compressible firm swelling over his palm as shown in the image. A few months back he got injured with a thorn. What is the presentation given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Implantation Dermoid

 

Option D:

 

Implantation / Acquired Dermoids:

 

  • This is an acquired condition that develops as a result of the penetration of epidermal fragments into the dermis.
  • The epidermis keeps expanding and eventually develops a cyst that is lined with stratified squamous epithelium and filled with keratin.
  • Seen in individuals like tailors, gardeners who sustain repeated minor injuries.
  • Sites: fingers, toes, feet.
  • "Minor Trauma- Epidermal Cells gets buried in the subcutaneous space à Cyst Formation.
  • Signs: Painless, Soft, Smooth, Adherent to Skin, Tensely Cystic, Mobile Swelling.
  • Managed by Surgical Excision, Careful complete excision; removal of the entire cyst wall is necessary to avoid the recurrence, under local anesthesia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ameloblastoma

 

  • Description: It is a benign tumor originating from odontogenic epithelium, primarily involved in tooth development.
  • Why it is not the answer: Ameloblastoma typically manifests in the jaw, especially the mandible as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The presentation in the palm after a thorn injury is inconsistent with this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Embryogenic Dermoid

 

  • Description: These cysts arise from trapped pluripotent cells during fetal development.
  • Why it is not the answer: Embryogenic dermoids are congenital and are frequently found at fusion lines such as the midline of the body. Their occurrence on the palm and their association with a traumatic event (like a thorn prick) is not typical.

 

Option C. Sequestration Dermoid

 

  • Description: Formed due to sequestration (separation) of ectodermal tissue during embryonic development.
  • Why it is not the answer: Like embryogenic dermoids, sequestration dermoids are commonly found in the midline, and their formation isn't associated with trauma or injury.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most likely diagnosis for a farmer presenting with a non-tender, non-mobile, non-compressible firm swelling on the palm following a puncture wound from a thorn is an implantation dermoid cyst (D).
  • These cysts are acquired through the traumatic implantation of epidermal elements into the dermis, which is consistent with the patient's history and clinical presentation.

 

Ref:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3481915

https://radiopaedia.org/cases/implantation-dermoid

https://dermnetnz.org/topics/dermoid-cyst

choices.text: It is more common in Girls
Lesions follow Blaschko's Lines
Mutation in IKBKG Gene
Peg-Shaped Teeth are seen

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents due to skin lesions that have been present since birth. The lesions initially appeared as blisters on her trunk and limbs as shown below, then evolved into wart-like rashes that followed a linear pattern. Currently, they have a swirled hyperpigmentation. The child's growth and development have been otherwise normal. Examination reveals that the teeth are small and conical in shape. The parents are concerned about the progression and the appearance of the skin lesions. Which of the following statement is INCORRECT about this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peg-Shaped Teeth are seen

 

The description given in this clinical vignette is classically describing the skin condition called Incontinentia pigmenti.

Option D.

 

  • Peg shaped teeth with a notch in the biting edge of incisors are seen in congenital syphilis, NOT Incontinentia pigmenti

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It is more common in girls:

 

  • Incontinentia pigmenti (IP) is indeed more common in girls due to its X-linked dominant inheritance pattern, which is often lethal in utero for males, leading to a predominance of the condition in females.

 

Option B. Lesions follow Blaschko's lines:

 

  • In IP, the skin lesions typically follow Blaschko's lines, which are patterns of skin development that are invisible except when revealed by certain skin conditions.

 

Option C. Mutation in IKBKG gene:

 

  • IP is caused by mutations in the IKBKG gene (also known as NEMO), which is involved in the regulation of immune responses and protection against cell death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peg-shaped teeth are an associated feature of Congenital syphilis, NOT Incontinentia pigmenti.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 70.11

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy presents with hypotonia, failure to thrive, and peculiar brittle, kinky hair. Laboratory tests show low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels. Genetic analysis is most likely to reveal a mutation in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ATP7A gene

 

Option C.

 

  • Menkes disease: This is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, which affects copper transport, leading to low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels.

  • Clinical features include hypotonia, developmental delay, failure to thrive, and characteristic kinky hair ("kinky hair disease").

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) The HFE gene

 

• This is associated with hereditary hemochromatosis, a condition characterized by iron overload, not copper deficiency.

 

Option B) Mutations in the alpha-synuclein gene

• These are associated with certain types of Parkinson's disease, not Menkes disease.


Option D) The ATP7B gene mutation

• This causes Wilson's disease, which also involves copper metabolism but leads to copper accumulation, not deficiency, and presents later in childhood or adolescence with hepatic and neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Menke's disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, leading to copper transport defects, and is characterized by hypotonia, developmental delay, and distinctive brittle, kinky hair.

 

Ref: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 937

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lichen Sclerosus

 

Option B:

 

The given image shows Lichen Sclerosus.

 

  • Lichen Sclerosus usually presents in postmenopausal women. Lichen sclerosus is one of the common dermatoses to affect the anogenital skin
  • The presenting symptom is usually itching, which is often severe and distressing. Patients may also complain of discomfort and dyspareunia if there is introital narrowing Perianal involvement frequently manifests as a figure-8 shape.
  • White, atrophic papules with abnormal anatomy distortion are the typical appearance. These papules may coalesce into plaques.
  • It is possible for introital stenosis, clitoral concealment, labia minora regression, and urethral obstruction to occur. A biopsy is required to rule out cancer.
  • Topical corticosteroids remain the first line of treatment.

 

Premalignant Lesions of Vulva:

 

  • Vulvar Intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN)
  • Paget’s disease
  • Lichensclerosus
  • Condylomaacuminata
  • Bowen disease (Erythroplasia of Queyrat)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Paget Disease:

 

 

  • Usually manifests as red, scaly, and crusted patches on the vulvar skin as shown in the image below.
  • It is often associated with an underlying malignancy. It does not present with white atrophic papules as shown in the question.

 

Option C. Lichen Planus:

 

  • Presents with purplish, flat-topped, itchy papules and plaques, often with a reticular pattern on mucous membranes, not typically white atrophic papules.

 

Option D. Angioma of Vulva:

 

  • This would present as a benign growth of small blood vessels and would be red and vascular in appearance as shown below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When encountering white atrophic papules and plaques on the vulva that may coalesce and distort the vulvar anatomy, lichen sclerosus should be considered as a primary diagnosis.

 

Ref: William’s Gynecology 4th Edition Page No 92-100, 688

 

Shaws Textbook of Gynecology, 17th Edition Page No 323, 473-475

 

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6298145/

choices.text: Pyoderma Gangrenosum
Venous Ulcer

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with a painful, necrotic ulcer on the lower leg. The ulcer has irregular, undermined borders and is associated with inflammatory pustules and violaceous hue at the periphery. There is no evidence of vascular compromise. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyoderma Gangrenosum

 

Option C.

 

  • It is a rare skin condition characterized by rapidly progressing skin ulcers with a purple border.
  • It is often associated with underlying systemic diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Histologically, it is characterized by a neutrophilic infiltrate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bechet's Disease

 

  • It is characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions.
  • While it can involve skin ulcers, the presentation is different from the rapidly progressing ulcers of pyoderma gangrenosum.

 

Option B. Arterial Ulcers

 

  • They are associated with arterial insufficiency and present with well-defined, punched-out ulcers, not the painful, rapidly progressing ulcers seen in this case.

 

Option D. Venous Ulcers

 

  • They typically present as painful, necrotic ulcers on the lower leg with irregular, undermined borders, but they are not associated with a purple border or neutrophilic infiltrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pyoderma gangrenosum is characterized by painful, rapidly progressing skin ulcers with a purple border, often associated with underlying systemic diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Histologically, it shows a neutrophilic infiltrate.

 

Ref: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 148.7
